{"blocks":[{"key":"5mlr1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"sjqe","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6jsf6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"93qj3","text":"Using Single Cell (thus, purified RNA should yield better stats)","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cbtd","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3eeia","text":"Sequence reads from each individual cell are normally in the range of 1–20 million, depending on the level of multiplexing in the sequencing. When sequencing 50-bp single-end reads, we find that normally 60% of reads map uniquely to the genome (20% multimapping and 20% with no match); of the uniquely mapping reads, \u003e60% of the reads map to annotated RefSeq exons, 20% intronic and 20% intergenic, but these values depend on the completeness of the gene annotations. The read coverage across transcripts should be even.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
